awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Nonconvex Optimization for High-Dimensional Signal Estimation: Theory and Fast Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
High-dimensional signal estimation plays fundamental roles in various engineering and science applications, such as medical imaging, video and network surveillance. Estimation procedures that maintain both statistical and computational efficacy are of great practical value, which translate into desiderata such as less time patients need to spend in a medical scanner, faster response to cyber attacks, and capabilities to handle very large datasets. While a lot of signal estimation tasks are naturally formulated as nonconvex optimization problems, existing results for nonconvex methods have several fundamental limitations, and the current state of the art is still limited in terms of when, why and which nonconvex approaches are effective for a given problem. The goal of this research program is to significantly deepen and broaden the understanding and applications of nonconvex optimization for high-dimensional signal estimation.

In this project, the investigators will study high-dimensional signal estimation via direct optimization of nonconvex, and potentially nonsmooth, loss functions, without resorting to convex relaxation. This research will explore geometric structures shared by nonconvex functions commonly encountered in signal estimation, and study the fundamental roles these structures play in determining the algorithmic convergence. These results will then be exploited as guidelines to develop fast and provably correct algorithms for estimating high-dimensional signals with physically induced structures and under streaming data observations. Specifically, the research program consists of three major thrusts: (1) understanding the geometric structures of important classes of nonconvex loss surfaces, and characterizing their impact on the convergence of optimization algorithms; (2) developing fast algorithms and the associated theory for the recovery of structured low-rank matrices; (3) designing new online algorithms that are time and space efficient under a streaming setting, with the capability of detecting and tracking the time-varying signals of interest.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop novel approaches for estimating high-dimensional signals and models that arise in modern machine learning and signal processing applications. These problems are typically formulated as challenging nonconvex optimization, and this project mainly focused on exploring geometric properties of the objective functions and latent low-rank structures of the system models for developing efficient algorithms. The following are the major research findings from the project.

1. We investigated a number of high-dimensional signal estimation problems, including phase retrieval, phase retrieval with outliers, and low-rank matrix recovery with arbitrary outliers. By formulating these problems as nonconvex optimization problems, we proposed novel approaches to solve these problems and characterized the sample and computational efficiency for these algorithms.

2. We studied large-scale nonconvex optimization problems, and develop a number of novel algorithms for solving these problems with high efficiency and scalability. In particular, we developed variance reduction algorithm SpiderBoost, cubic regularization method with momentum, stochastic variance-reduced cubic-regularization (SVRC) method, and variance-reduced algorithms with adaptive batch size. We further showed that these algorithms improve the computational complexity or convergence speed of the previously known algorithms. 

3. We investigated the geometric properties of nonconvex objective functions with neural network models and characterized their impact on the optimization performance. For the loss function with linear neural network models, we characterized the properties of critical points and the landscape around these critical points, which are highly important to determine the convergence performance of optimization algorithms. We further studied the landscape of the population risk function under convolutional neural networks with ReLU activations, and showed that it is strongly convex in a local neighborhood of the ground truth, which further enabled us to show that gradient descent with random initialization converges to the global minimum at a linear rate.

4. We investigated reinforcement learning algorithms for solving online decision making problems, which are formulated as Markov decision processes (MDPs). In particular, we improved the analysis for various policy gradient algorithms including actor-critic (AC) algorithm and natural AC algorithms under Markovian sampling, and single-sample two-timescale actor-critic (AC) algorithms for solving the linear quadratic regulator (LQR) problem. We also provided the first convergence analysis for Adam-type policy gradient algorithms, and developed the convergence analysis for double Q-learning algorithms.

5. We explored the online decision making problems under distribution drift, which is formulated as MDPs with off-policy data. We proposed a new emphatic temporal difference learning approach for value function evaluation, which enjoys the polynomial sample complexity (whereas the previous approaches suffer exponential sample complexity). We also developed a unified approach for general value function evaluation under off-policy data, which improves the convergence of the previous approaches. We further developed a doubly robust off-policy AC algorithm for finding a near-optimal policy, and provided the convergence guarantee for such an algorithm. 

The results and findings of this project have been disseminated through numerous journal and conference publications as well as conference presentations in several research communities, including signal processing, machine learning, optimization, and information theory communities. The PI Liang gave seminar talks about the findings of this project at several universities, and keynote talks in 2019 IEEE MLSP conference and 2019 TRIPODS 2nd Southwest Summer Conference. The PI Liang also gave tutorials based on the findings of this project at 2021 IEEE BigData conference, 2022 IEEE ICASSP conference, and 2021 IEEE ISIT conference.

The students working on the project learned new mathematical techniques on the topics of high-dimensional signal estimation, nonconvex optimization, reinforcement learning, and machine learning. They also had opportunities to collaborate with other researchers in the field and to present the research results at various conferences.
